title: Inhibition of human maltase-glucoamylase, sucrase-isomaltase and α-amylases by gallotannins and ellagitannins.
abstract: This research explored the inhibitory effects of walnut (Juglans regia) (poly)phenols on key starch digesting enzymes including human brush border α-glucosidases, maltase-glucoamylase (MGAM) and sucrase-isomaltase (SI), as well as pancreatic and salivary α-amylases. SI was obtained from Caco-2/TC7 cell-free extracts, while, for the first time, full-length MGAM was obtained from human A549 cell lysates. Among the tested gallo- and ellagitannins, 1,2,6-tri-O-galloyl-β-d-glucose and 1,3,4,6-tetra-O-galloyl-β-d-glucose were good inhibitors of human SI activity (IC50values of 29.7 ± 5.5 and 45.1 ± 4.7 μM), with the latter also effectively inhibiting human α-amylases. In a (poly)phenolic-rich extract from walnuts, 1,2,6-tri-O-galloyl-β-d-glucose contributed 60 % of total sucrase inhibition, whereas 1,3,4,6-tetra-O-galloyl-β-d-glucose accounted for only 2 % of sucrase inhibition. All tested gallo- and ellagitannins demonstrated poor inhibition of maltotriose (glucoamylase) hydrolysing activity of human MGAM, whereas the walnut extract inhibited maltase activity by ~50 %. The data show that (poly)phenols from walnuts can inhibit only some of the enzymes involved in starch digestion.
